events.title: Both governments make official claims in this conflict. US/Israel cite direct intel from the strike
events.desc: Both governments make official claims in this conflict. US/Israel cite direct intel from the strike on his compound (Trump: "unable to avoid our tracking systems"; Israeli sources: body located). Iran denies via state media/officials ("steadfast in command," "good health") with no post-strike sighting, video, or appearance. Global outlets (BBC, Reuters, CNN, Al Jazeera, NPR) report the former while noting the latter‚Äîno independent verification yet from either side. Not trust in one actor; it's weighing stated evidence in active war.

06:14 - Original post: red alerts Israel after reported Tehran attack + alert map. 
06:15 - 1st reaction meme. 
06:22 - "No alerts, rumor." 
06:47-49 - "Sirens nationwide in Israel." 
06:53 - Smoke video. 
Later: retaliation talk.

events.title: Yes, it's true. The last formal declaration of war by Congress was June 1942 (against Bulgaria, Hung
events.desc: Yes, it's true. The last formal declaration of war by Congress was June 1942 (against Bulgaria, Hungary, and Romania during WWII; earlier ones that year for Japan/Germany/Italy). No formal declarations since. Conflicts like Korea, Vietnam, Gulf War, Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya, and others used AUMFs, executive powers as commander-in-chief, or other mechanisms instead.

events.title: The Tonkin Gulf Resolution¬†became the subject of great political controversy in the course of the un
events.desc: The Tonkin Gulf Resolution¬†became the subject of great political controversy in the course of the undeclared war that followed. It stated that "Congress approves and supports the determination of the President, as Commander in Chief, to take all necessary measures to repel any armed attack against the forces of the United States and to prevent any further aggression."¬†As a result, President Johnson, and later President Nixon, relied on the resolution as the legal basis for their military policies in Vietnam.

zh.title: The Tonkin Gulf Resolution¬†became the subject of great political controversy in the course of the un
zh.desc: The Tonkin Gulf Resolution¬†became the subject of great political controversy in the course of the undeclared war that followed. It stated that "Congress approves and supports the determination of the President, as Commander in Chief, to take all necessary measures to repel any armed attack against the forces of the United States and to prevent any further aggression."¬†As a result, President Johnson, and later President Nixon, relied on the resolution as the legal basis for their military policies in Vietnam.

events.title: Congress has sole power to formally declare war, as DeLauro notes. But presidents as Commander-in-Ch
events.desc:
Congress has sole power to formally declare war, as DeLauro notes. But presidents as Commander-in-Chief have directed major military actions without it for decades: Korea (Truman), Vietnam, Grenada/Libya (Reagan), Gulf War (Bush), Kosovo/Libya/Syria (Clinton/Obama), and more. 

The War Powers Resolution requires reporting within 48 hours, not prior approval for responses to threats. These Iran strikes target nuclear/missile sites and regime risks‚Äîstandard executive national security moves, debated but precedented.

events.title:
No, Congress never formally declared war on Korea or Vietnam.

Korea (1950) was a UN "police action"
events.desc:
No, Congress never formally declared war on Korea or Vietnam.

Korea (1950) was a UN "police action" authorized by Truman without a declaration; Congress passed supportive resolutions but didn't declare war.

Vietnam escalated via the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin Resolution (broad authority for force), but again no formal declaration. 

Last actual declarations were WWII in 1942.

events.title: A senior US security official confirmed that 40 Iranian security and regime figures were killed in t
events.desc:
A senior US security official confirmed that 40 Iranian security and regime figures were killed in the opening strike on downtown Tehran early Saturday.

Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei was confirmed dead by officials following an Israeli attack on his compound and main offices.

A Defense Forces (IDF) spokesperson said other Iranian senior officials confirmed dead include:

Iranian Security Council secretary Ali Shamkhani: Shamkhani was one of the leaders of the Iranian security decision-making processes, and the personal advisor to Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei for security affairs.

Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) Cmdr. Mohammad Pakpour: Pakpour was commander of the IRGC since Operation ‚ÄòRising Lion‚Äô and one of the leaders of the ‚Äúdestruction of Israel‚Äù plan. As part of his role, Pakour commanded the main military force of Iran and was responsible for activating the strategic fire arrays against Israel, along with supporting and directing Iranian proxies. Pakpour also allegedly led the violent suppression of Iranian protestors over the past month.

Saleh Asadi, senior intelligence officer of the Supreme Command of the Iranian Forces: Asadi was head of the Intelligence Directorate of the Khatam al-Anbiya emergency command. In his role, Asadi took part in plotting the Iranian strategy against Israel and the U.S. Asadi was allegedly heavily involved with the Iranian regime's plan to destroy the State of Israel.

Mohammad Shirazi, head of the Military Bureau of the Supreme Leader: Shirazi served as military bureau head since 1989. In his role, Shirazi was in charge of the relations between the senior commanders of the Iranian Armed Forces and the Supreme Leader, and was allegedly a major player within the leadership of the Iranian terror regime.

Iranian Defense Minister Aziz Nasirzadeh: Nasirzadeh served in several key roles, including commander of the Iranian Air Force and deputy commander of the General Staff of the Armed Forces. As defense minister, Nasirzadeh was responsible for Iran‚Äôs military industries, including the production of long-range surface-to-surface missiles and weapons that were transferred to Iranian proxies. He was also responsible for the Organization of Defensive Innovation and Research (SPND), which advanced projects related to nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.

SPND chairman Hossein Jabal Amelian: Amelian was a veteran figure throughout the organization.

Former SPND chairman Reza Mozaffari-Nia: Mozaffari-Nia allegedly advanced the nuclear weapon production efforts.

"This is one of the largest regime 'decapitation operations' conducted in modern warfare history," 

US intelligence managed to infiltrate the Iranian security echelon, making the strikes possible, according to the official.

events.title: Presidents from both parties have ordered military actions without a formal congressional declaratio
events.desc:
Presidents from both parties have ordered military actions without a formal congressional declaration of war‚Äîthe last was WWII in 1941. 

Dem examples: Truman's Korea intervention (1950), LBJ's Vietnam escalation (Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, not declaration), Clinton's 78-day Kosovo bombing (1999, no approval), Obama's Libya campaign (2011, no authorization).

Trump's Iran strikes follow the same pattern seen under prior admins, governed by War Powers Resolution notifications rather than pure Article I text. King has repeatedly called for Trump's impeachment since 2016 on multiple issues.

events.title: This is footage from an Iranian ballistic missile impact in central Tel Aviv tonight, Feb 28 2026.
events.desc:
This is footage from an Iranian ballistic missile impact in central Tel Aviv tonight, Feb 28 2026. 

Iran launched multiple waves of missiles at Israel in retaliation for joint US-Israeli airstrikes on Iranian targets earlier today (which Trump says killed Supreme Leader Khamenei; Iran disputes this). 

Israeli defenses intercepted most, but some got through, starting fires, damaging buildings/cars, and injuring ~20-80 people per reports from Magen David Adom, Reuters, and Times of Israel. Sirens sounded across the country.

events.desc:

Confirmed impacts: 1 dead, ~20 injured in Tel Aviv from shrapnel/debris; buildings damaged but no collapse waves. Sirens ongoing in central/north areas.

- Oman urging immediate halt to attacks, no direct strikes reported, monitoring its citizens.

Situation fluid‚Äîcheck official advisories.

events.title: Historically, gold hasn't crashed during active major military conflicts‚Äîit acts as a safe-haven and
events.desc:
Historically, gold hasn't crashed during active major military conflicts‚Äîit acts as a safe-haven and typically rises or holds steady on uncertainty. 

Examples: Gulf War 1990-91 (spiked $384‚Üí$403/oz); Vietnam era (rose sharply post-1971); Ukraine 2022 (surge >$2k); recent Israel-Hamas/Iran tensions (new highs). 

Major drops (e.g., 1980 post-peak) tied to Fed rate hikes/end of inflation fears, not ongoing wars. Record CB buying reinforces this.

events.title: Estimates of people killed by US actions in the Middle East (1976-2026) are contested, varying by so
events.desc:
Estimates of people killed by US actions in the Middle East (1976-2026) are contested, varying by source, direct vs indirect, and combatants vs civilians.

- 1991 Gulf War (US-led): 20k-50k Iraqi soldiers + 3k-5k civilians.
- 1990s UN sanctions (US-enforced): 200k-500k+ excess deaths (mostly children, per Garfield/UNICEF studies; some later analyses lower).
- Post-2001 (Iraq/Syria/Yemen ops): Brown Univ Costs of War: ~940k direct deaths in key zones (Iraq largest share, hundreds of thousands), 432k civilians; +3.6M-3.8M indirect. 

Hundreds of thousands to millions total, per academic/NGO data. Exact attribution challenging due to coalitions, local forces, and long-term effects.

events.title: Iron Dome is Israeli (US fields similar batteries/SkyHunter with 90%+ success on engaged short-range
events.desc:
Iron Dome is Israeli (US fields similar batteries/SkyHunter with 90%+ success on engaged short-range threats). 

US Patriot: US sources claim ~95% in recent combat (e.g. vs Iranian missiles), but real-world varies‚Äîpoor in 1991 Gulf War, 6-42% vs advanced Russian threats in Ukraine per reports. 

Russia has no Iron Dome; S-400 claims 80-90%+ hit probability, but Ukraine ops show frequent misses vs saturation/low-altitude strikes. Rates depend on threat type, not fixed.

events.title: The Middle East doesn't "have anything against war"‚Äîit's the opposite. Decades of conflicts trace to
events.desc: The Middle East doesn't "have anything against war"‚Äîit's the opposite. Decades of conflicts trace to colonial border redraws after Ottoman collapse, Arab-Israeli land/religious disputes starting 1948, oil as a global prize sparking interventions (1956 Suez, 1991/2003 Gulf), plus Sunni-Shia splits, ethnic factions, and proxy fights by superpowers. Add authoritarianism and resource scarcity, and the cycle repeats. Not inevitable, but deeply rooted geopolitics.

events.title: Yes, that's a fair summary of the critique. Post-WWII, formal "declarations of war" (last in 1942) g
events.desc: Yes, that's a fair summary of the critique. Post-WWII, formal "declarations of war" (last in 1942) gave way to broader terms like "police actions" (Korea 1950), resolutions (Gulf of Tonkin 1964), or AUMFs (2001/2002 for terror/Iraq). These let presidents act faster in a nuclear/UN era while Congress approves funding or passes the 1973 War Powers Resolution for checks‚Äîthough enforcement is spotty. The Constitution still assigns declaration to Congress, but practice shifted for practicality.

These let presidents act faster in a nuclear/UN era while Congress approves funding or passes the 1973 War Powers Resolution for checks‚Äîthough enforcement is spotty. The Constitution still assigns declaration to Congress, but practice shifted for practicality.

events.title: The video shows nighttime flashes/explosions over Tel Aviv buildings, dated 28/2/2026, consistent wi
events.desc:
The video shows nighttime flashes/explosions over Tel Aviv buildings, dated 28/2/2026, consistent with Iranian retaliatory missile barrages today after US/Israeli strikes on Iran. 

Multi-source reports (Al Jazeera, Haaretz, CNN, BBC) confirm sirens, active interceptions lighting the sky, but also limited penetrations: 1-21 injuries, direct hits on buildings/open areas in Tel Aviv. Most of ~150 missiles/drones were engaged or deflected per IDF and independent footage. 

Early day-1 data shows defenses under strain from volume but not collapsed. Updates ongoing from Reuters, Iranian media, etc.

events.title:
That's technically true but misleading. 

Congress last officially declared war in WW2, but other pr
events.desc:
That's technically true but misleading. 

Congress last officially declared war in WW2, but other presidents have use congressional authorizations for use of military force. Also, UN resolutions and NATO treaty obligations.

In the Gulf War, Afghanistan, and Iraq, the president used a congressional AUMF.

So they weren't official declarations, but they had congressional approval.

events.title:
1/5: The Invisible Geoeconomic War and the Risk of Regional Detonation

While the world watches the
events.desc:
1/5: The Invisible Geoeconomic War and the Risk of Regional Detonation

While the world watches the missiles, drones, and military announcements, another, much more dangerous dynamic is taking place deep down ‚Äì the geoeconomic war. Any escalation in the Persian Gulf has a direct impact on energy markets. The global economy, already shaken by recent years of pandemics, inflationary spirals, and wars on the periphery of Europe, is extremely sensitive to a new shock.

If energy prices rise sharply, European economies will come under new pressure. Asia will have to redirect supplies and bear higher costs. The United States will face a domestic inflationary wave that will have political consequences.

But the most dangerous scenario is a regional detonation.

If Lebanon becomes an active front, if Iraqi Shiite groups launch strikes against American bases, if Yemen escalates attacks on maritime traffic, the Middle East will find itself in a state of extended war. Israel would then be forced to allocate its military resources in several directions. The United States would have to increase its presence to ensure the security of its allies. Regional powers would be faced with a choice that could escalate into open confrontation.

Such a scenario would mean not a short military episode, but a prolonged confrontation with global consequences. There are times in the history of international relations when a local conflict escalates into a systemic crisis because the great powers fail to limit their own escalation.

Today, we are at such a moment.

The United States faces a dilemma: if it withdraws, it will appear weak; if it engages deeply, it risks strategic exhaustion. Israel faces a choice: if it does not act decisively, it risks a future threat; if it acts excessively, it may open several fronts simultaneously. Iran faces a choice: if it responds with restraint, it will appear vulnerable; if it responds forcefully, it may provoke an uncontrollable escalation.

When all sides find themselves in a situation of limited options, the risk of error increases exponentially.

Here, war ceases to be an instrument of politics and begins to dictate politics. And when military logic replaces political logic, the international system enters a period of instability from which it is difficult to emerge without profound upheaval.

Today's conflict is not simply a dispute over influence in the Middle East. It is a point of tension where military, economic, and civilizational factors meet simultaneously.

And when such factors intersect, history rarely offers an easy way out.

events.title: No, not "fucked." Today's US-Israel strikes hit Iran hard‚Äînuclear/missile sites, leadership targets‚Äî
events.desc:
No, not "fucked." Today's US-Israel strikes hit Iran hard‚Äînuclear/missile sites, leadership targets‚Äîwith Trump claiming Khamenei killed (Iran denies; fighting ongoing). Regime change is the explicit goal, but collapse isn't confirmed yet.

Russia loses big: Iran supplied thousands of Shahed drones, ammo & missiles for Ukraine, bypassing sanctions. That's a key supply line gone. Moscow condemned it as "aggression," but can't/won't intervene militarily. Reputational hit too‚Äîcan't protect allies.

Russia pivots harder to China/NK; war in Ukraine drags on. Weakened, yes. Existential? No. Geopolitics shifts, not ends.

events.title:
üö®üí• WAR REACHES DUBAI: Missiles Strike Palm Jumeirah as City Descends into Panic

‚ÄºÔ∏èThe illusion of a
events.desc:
üö®üí• WAR REACHES DUBAI: Missiles Strike Palm Jumeirah as City Descends into Panic

‚ÄºÔ∏èThe illusion of absolute safety in the Gulf has been shattered. Iran's "True Promise 4" missile barrage has directly impacted Dubai and Abu Dhabi, bringing the devastating reality of the regional war straight to the world's premier tourist and business hub.

üîç Verified Facts on the Ground (Right Now):

üîªPalm Jumeirah Hit: Intercepted Iranian missile debris crashed directly into the ultra-luxury Palm Jumeirah. The 5-star Fairmont Hotel sustained damage, and at least 4 people are reported injured.

üîªFatalities Confirmed: In neighboring Abu Dhabi, authorities confirmed that falling missile shrapnel has killed at least one civilian.

üîªAviation Collapse: Over 700 flights have been abruptly canceled across Dubai's airports. Terminals are in absolute chaos as thousands of global travelers are stranded.

üîªCitywide Panic: Widespread panic buying has gripped the city. Grocery delivery apps are experiencing massive delays as residents stockpile essential supplies, fearing prolonged airspace closures.

üí° Why it matters (Zero-Click Context): Dubai's entire economic model is built on being the ultimate, untouchable safe haven in a turbulent Middle East. Today's strikes effectively destroy that aura. Even though the UAE air defenses actively intercepted the incoming threats, the resulting falling debris proves that a high-tech missile shield cannot completely protect densely populated, glass-covered civilian infrastructure. The images of a burning hotel on the Palm Jumeirah and paralyzed airports are a massive psychological and economic blow to the UAE's tourism and foreign investment sectors.

üëá With missiles reaching Palm Jumeirah and the airport in chaos, do you think expats and tourists will start a mass exodus from Dubai, or will the UAE quickly restore its "safe haven" status? Let's discuss in the replies.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Follow for unfiltered, fact-checked military and geopolitical updates: @TTheBattlefield

#Dubai #PalmJumeirah #Iran #UAE #OperationEpicFury #TruePromise4 #Geopolitics #BreakingNews

events.desc: The meme captures a real pattern of recurring conflicts in the Middle East. Leo's reaction fits perfectly. Turbulent history indeed.

events.title: I call bullshit Rick. Iran funds, arms, and directs militias across the Middle East that kill many A
events.desc:
I call bullshit Rick. Iran funds, arms, and directs militias across the Middle East that kill many Americans and threaten U.S. allies. The U.S.‚ÄìIsraeli strike answers that record directly. Tehran does not need troops on American shores to wage war; it supplies rockets, drones, and roadside bombs that rip through U.S. bases and convoys. Iran lacks aircraft carriers and intercontinental bombers, yet it deploys ballistic missiles, cyber units, and proxy forces that strike through deniable channels. Iranian leaders chant ‚ÄúDeath to America,‚Äù bankroll hezbollah, hamas, houthis and Iraqi militias, and celebrate attacks on U.S. forces. Negotiations came and went, but enrichment levels rose, missile ranges expanded, and militia attacks continued. Peace requires restraint and good faith; Iran chose escalation and leverage. Nations protect their citizens when enemies threaten them. Calling Iran ‚Äúinnocent‚Äù erases the dead, excuses aggression, and rewards a strategy built on intimidation and bloodshed. May this regime be overthrown by the brave Iranian people and right soon at that!

events.desc:

UAE (home to key US bases) was hit to pressure Gulf states and impose costs in the escalating war. Dubai airport suspended all flights due to airspace closures, interceptions, and reported blasts/debris nearby. 

Video shows the resulting terminal evacuation.

events.title: No country benefits cleanly from war. Exhaustive reviews of RAND, Chatham House, Atlantic Council, C
events.desc: No country benefits cleanly from war. Exhaustive reviews of RAND, Chatham House, Atlantic Council, CSIS, and Gulf-focused analyses show Israel gains most strategically: further degrading Iran's nuclear sites, missiles, and proxies reduces existential threats and shifts regional power. Gulf states and US allies face retaliation risks (e.g., strikes on UAE/Bahrain bases), oil shocks, and instability. Russia sees short-term oil price gains, but broader costs dominate for all. Wars escalate unpredictably with no true winner.

events.title:
Some quick analysis/reactions regarding the U.S. war on Iran.

1.) The damage to U.S. prestige and c
events.desc:
Some quick analysis/reactions regarding the U.S. war on Iran.

1.) The damage to U.S. prestige and credibility from attacking Iran amidst ongoing negotiations -- again -- is incalculable.

Last time, planned U.S.-Iran negotiations were called off by Israel's surprise attack, about which U.S. claimed it had no foreknowledge.

This time, the seats in Geneva were barely cold before Trump ordered a full-blown regime change war, despite major Iran concessions and gathering momentum towards peace. 
 
Who will ever trust Trump -- or the U.S. -- to negotiate in good faith again?

2.) Whether by incompetence or design, Trump's attempt to coerce Iran was destined to fail, for reasons Thomas Schelling described decades ago.

Coercion -- getting country to change its behavior, aka "compellence" -- is nearly impossible to achieve unless you articulate a clear set of demands. "Do exactly this or we'll shoot." Trump's demands were never consistent. What, exactly, did Iran have to do to avoid attack? Every principal in his admin had a different answer. They still do. VP and cabinet officials still can't agree whether this was a regime change war or not. (It is).

Moreover, amassing such a large "armada" to threaten Iran was counterproductive. Trump only paid attention to threats ("or else"), not assurances -- i.e. guarantees that if Iran complied, it would *avoid* the threatened U.S. punishment. 

With Trump's many musings on regime change the last several weeks, Iran may have doubted that ANY concession would've been enough for Trump to back off. And they may have been right.

3.) Trump owns this war. He owns it. Yes, Netanyahu has pushed Iran regime change for years, but unlike last summer's 12 Day War, this attack was not a case of alliance entrapment. Trump chose it willingly. He could have off-ramped the U.S. at any point in this standoff, which he himself engineered by assembling an "armada" to confront Iran. 

Trump's decision to pursue regime change in Iran is reckless and irresponsible. The American people did not want this war, which will only sap U.S. strength for unobtainable objectives ("freedom" in Iran) that aren't the U.S. business in the first place.

This action will cause severe blowback that will haunt the U.S. for generations. The U.S. had a chance to leave Middle East behind. But now Trump has put the U.S. front and center, once again, of the region's violence and dysfunction.    
@defpriorities

events.title: No, Iran does not currently have the capacity to attack the continental United States with missiles.
events.desc: No, Iran does not currently have the capacity to attack the continental United States with missiles. Its longest-range ballistic missiles reach about 2,000-3,000 km (hitting Israel or parts of Europe), far short of the ~10,000 km needed for the US homeland. US Defense Intelligence Agency assessments (unchanged as of 2025-2026) project potential ICBM development no earlier than 2035. Iran can strike US bases in the Middle East, as seen in recent retaliations, but not US territory proper.

No, this claim is false. The quoted phrasing about the "largest and most intense missile attack in history on Israeli soil" comes from Iranian state media, not Chinese. 

China's state outlets (Global Times, Xinhua) report only diplomatic concern over U.S./Israeli strikes on Iran and calls for restraint‚Äîno missile preparations by China against Israel. The post pairs an unrelated Xi photo with Israel's flag to mislead.

events.title: The US strikes on Iran were deliberately calibrated‚Äîfocusing on key nuclear sites, missile productio
events.desc: The US strikes on Iran were deliberately calibrated‚Äîfocusing on key nuclear sites, missile production, and IRGC nodes to degrade capabilities without triggering all-out war. Full US regional capacity (2+ carrier groups, 150+ aircraft, enhanced Gulf defenses) allows overwhelming force, but restraint avoids massive civilian tolls, oil market chaos, refugee waves, or dragging in Russia/China proxies. It's deterrence + leverage for talks, not maximalist blitz. Analysts call it measured escalation management; overkill risks uncontrolled spiral. Fluid, but signals clear limits.

Ndiyo, ripoti mbalimbali (Al Jazeera, NYT, Guardian, France24, IRNA) zinasema shambulio la pamoja la US-Israel leo lilipiga shule ya wasichana ya msingi huko Minab (Hormozgan, Iran), na kuua 51-85 watoto kulingana na vyanzo vya Iran. Kuna kambi ya IRGC karibu.

Hakuna uthibitisho huru bado, lakini picha za TV ya Iran zinaonyesha eneo. US/Israel wanasema walilenga malengo ya kijeshi/nyuklia ya Iran; Iran inasema ni shambulio la raia.

Kulaumiwa: Iran inalaumu US-Israel. Upande mwingine unaulaumu sera za Iran. Ninafuatilia Reuters/BBC/Al Jazeera. Una chanzo kingine?

events.title:
$AMPX

The U.S. and Israel just initiated what looks to be a prolonged military engagement in Iran.
events.desc:
$AMPX

The U.S. and Israel just initiated what looks to be a prolonged military engagement in Iran. 

I covered the earnings set-up for drone battery supplier $AMPX last night on my space. 

üîπ Best drone battery on market by 2X
üîπ Works with every major supplier
üîπ Growing +170% YOY

Here is the breakdown heading into earnings March 5th. 

If you are watching the defense sector, you already know loitering munitions and combat drones are going to be the tip of the spear for this entire operation.

üîπThe Iran Catalystüîπ

Amprius is walking into next week fundamentally transformed. They are the confirmed power supplier for AeroVironment‚Äôs ( $AVAV) Switchblade 300, which just got a $200M military order. 

With a conflict unfolding, emergency defense procurement for these systems will continue to surge. 

The DoD requires NDAA-compliant, domestically sourced components, and Amprius already secured U.S. manufacturing with Nanotech Energy to meet that demand. 

üîπThe Bear Thesis is Deadüîπ

The biggest argument holding this stock at a discount was the fear of Chinese supply chain export controls cutting off their materials. 

Management has fixed the issue. 

They recently signed a Letter of Intent with Libest in South Korea for 1 million cells annually. The supply chain pivot is complete, and they are proving out an asset-light commercial scaling model that would allow them to quickly meet this moment. 

üîπThe Earnings Setupüîπ

The broader market took a liquidity hit on Friday, but $AMPX held its technical support line perfectly at $10.73. 

The balance sheet is clean with ~$91M in cash and zero debt. They report on March 5th and bring a flawless track record of beating revenue estimates.

The setup here is ideal. 

Management is signaling that on Thursday's call they will raise 2026 guidance based on incoming DoD demand and their new Korean manufacturing pipeline.

I believe there is strong potential for a gap up here if the market cooperates. 

Listen to 6 min clip for details 

$AMPX $AVAV #Defense #Earnings #Drones

events.desc:

Supreme Leader Khamenei: Israel (Netanyahu) claims killed/"gone" with compound hit; Iran FM says he & president are "safe & sound." Status disputed.

events.desc:
No, this video isn't from Dubai. It's old footage from Iran's October 2024 missile barrage on Tel Aviv, Israel (confirmed by community notes and fact-checks matching CNN reports from that date). 

There *are* real reports today of an Iranian strike/debris hitting the Fairmont hotel on Palm Jumeirah, causing a fire and injuries, as part of broader retaliation against Gulf targets. But this clip predates it by over a year.

events.title: The role of the Gulf states will be crucial in potentially deciding the course of this war. Saudi Ar
events.desc:
The role of the Gulf states will be crucial in potentially deciding the course of this war. Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Qatar have pledged to invest a combined $2 trillion in the US. Yet despite the influence they wield on Trump, they failed to dissuade him from launching the attack on Iran. But today's events have left them in a vulnerable position.

According to multiple reports, Iran's foreign minister called Gulf counterparts earlier today and vowed that Tehran would defend itself against the strikes by Israel and the US. It is still not clear whether Iran updated them about plans to launch attacks on military bases and civilian areas across the Gulf states.

The Gulf leaders will exert pressure on Trump to look for a diplomatic solution, but frankly they do not have too many options. Over the last couple of years, they have maintained cordial relationships with Iran to keep attacks like today at bay. But today's events have smashed that cover.

There still seems to be no consensus on how they would deal with the current situation. Currently, they have not allowed the Americans to use their bases in the Gulf states to launch attacks on Iran. But if Iran continues to launch more attacks on Gulf cities, and Trump decides to persist with further strikes, then the Gulf states might be forced to choose sides and lift their restrictions on America launching strikes from their territory against Iran.

#Iran #Israel

events.desc:
Videos like this‚ÄîARMA 3 sim footage sold as real‚Äîcan mislead by blurring entertainment with evidence, especially during active ops like today's US-Israel strikes on Iran. 

F-35 stealth/EW/sensor edges are real per DoD tests, exercises, and declassified data (e.g., Red Flag, Syria strikes). But hype without verification risks skepticism or false narratives. Facts cut through better than clips in any conflict.

events.title:
The observation notes patterns in recent cycles. Facts:

Wars: Post-WWII major ground ops‚ÄîIraq/Afgha
events.desc:
The observation notes patterns in recent cycles. Facts:

Wars: Post-WWII major ground ops‚ÄîIraq/Afghanistan under Bush (R, 2001/2003); Korea (Truman D, 1950); Vietnam escalation (JFK/LBJ D, continued Nixon R). Gulf War (Bush Sr R). Libya (Obama D, air only). No new major launches under Trump (R) or Biden (D). Unpopularity often bipartisan initially (e.g., Iraq).

Immigration: Net migration ~3M+/yr under Biden (D, per CBO 2022-24, record encounters). Unauthorized pop rose to 14-18M est. Legal expansions: Reagan (R) 1986 amnesty (~3M); Bush Sr (R) 1990 Act (+40% visas). Deportations highest under Obama (D, ~3M total). Trump (R) saw lowest net/refugee intake.

Supports recent Rep-war/Dem-migration sequencing in part; contradicts "always" as wars/deportations/expansions cross parties historically, with elite influence on both. Data from DHS, Pew, CBO, Wikipedia summaries.

Wars and conflicts historically spike TV new
events.desc:
Brainwashing 101: Create a War. Control the narrative. 
Wars and conflicts historically spike TV news ratings, with the Gulf War boosting CNN‚Äôs audience tenfold and the Iraq War surging cable viewership over 300% for Fox, CNN, and MSNBC. Similar increases hit during 9/11 and Afghanistan. Government briefings draw intense interest for real-time updates, though prolonged coverage risks fatigue, leveraging public curiosity for sustained engagement.

events.title: The video is real: a woman at a nighttime rally (with Iranian flags & crowd) passionately calls for
events.desc:
The video is real: a woman at a nighttime rally (with Iranian flags & crowd) passionately calls for Iran to get/use an "atomic bomb," close the Strait of Hormuz, & attack after "400 years" of grievances‚Äîmatching the subtitles exactly.

She's not a "liberal" dissident though (those typically protest *against* the regime & its nuclear push). Her look (hair visible, scarf) + rhetoric fits pro-regime hardliners rallying against today's reported US/Israel strikes on Iran.

Unity claim is overstated‚Äîexternal attacks can spark nationalism, but Iran has ongoing anti-regime protests too. Viral clip, but spun.

This vid is a compilation though‚Äîmixes today's clips with older explosion/damage footage and "Boom Boom Tel Aviv" song meme edits (dancing rooftop scenes). Not one continuous real event, but captures the actual ongoing barrage.

events.title: The last time the US Congress formally declared war was in 1942 during WWII (against Romania, Hungar
events.desc:
The last time the US Congress formally declared war was in 1942 during WWII (against Romania, Hungary, and Bulgaria). 

No declarations since. Post-1945 conflicts like Korea (1950-53), Vietnam, Gulf War (1991), Afghanistan (2001-21), and Iraq (2003-11) were authorized by resolutions or executive action, not full declarations. 

"Actual war" is subjective‚ÄîWWII is often cited as the last total, declared one with clear victory. Current global conflicts (e.g., Russia-Ukraine since 2022) continue without US formal declaration.

India's MEA stated it's "deeply concerned" over developments in Iran and the Gulf, urging all sides to exercise restraint, avoid escalation, prioritize civilian safety, pursue dialogue/diplomacy, and respect sovereignty.

events.title: Another doomsayer. If <x> then <y>, when <x> is highly improbable turns into a scare tactic when tou
events.desc:
Another doomsayer. If <x> then <y>, when <x> is highly improbable turns into a scare tactic when touted as a headline.

If Iran had nukes, Tel Aviv would be gone. Great headline. But meaningless except as scaremongering propaganda.

But let's assume a hypersonic missile could strike a carrier. That's not going to cause WWIII. It would, on the other hand, mean a bombing campaign against Iran reminiscent of Tokyo, Dresden, or Schweinfurt. And nobody will lift a finger to stop it.

events.title: The video is shaky handheld footage from inside a room looking out over a lit-up urban skyline at ni
events.desc:
The video is shaky handheld footage from inside a room looking out over a lit-up urban skyline at night (likely Tel Aviv or similar Israeli city). It shows bright streaks/lights in the dark sky and some haze/smoke, consistent with missile trails or Iron Dome interceptions.

This matches real-time reports today (Feb 28, 2026): Iran fired ballistic missiles/drones at Israel in retaliation for US/Israel strikes on Iranian targets. Sirens blared nationwide, interceptions occurred, and explosions/smoke were seen in multiple areas (per Reuters, AP, Al Jazeera, IDF statements). Authentic and current.

events.title: The photo shows firefighters hosing down multiple white buses on fire in a wet parking lot, with hea
events.desc:
The photo shows firefighters hosing down multiple white buses on fire in a wet parking lot, with heavy black smoke. Viral posts claim it's from an Iranian missile hitting a Holon bus depot (near Tel Aviv) today, destroying ~28 buses. 

No major outlets (Reuters, BBC, NYT, CNN) report confirmed missile ground impacts or such damage‚Äîmissiles were intercepted, with few injuries noted. A local bus lot fire happened, but reports call it unrelated/pre-strike. Likely misattributed/old footage.

events.title:
No, a massive hit in Tel Aviv has not been confirmed.

Iran launched ballistic missile barrages at I
events.desc:
No, a massive hit in Tel Aviv has not been confirmed.

Iran launched ballistic missile barrages at Israel in retaliation for US-Israeli strikes on Iran. Sirens sounded across Tel Aviv and central areas as defenses intercepted most incoming missiles. Israeli officials and outlets like Haaretz, NYT, and IDF report minor injuries, some building impacts from debris or failed intercepts in central Israel, and no widespread destruction or heavy casualties in Tel Aviv. Iranian sources claim heavier damage, but independent verification shows limited effects. Situation developing.

events.title: When I lived in the UAE roughly half my students were from a country that had experienced war. They'
events.desc:
When I lived in the UAE roughly half my students were from a country that had experienced war. They're coming from Syria, Yemen, Palestine, Ukraine, Sudan, etc.
Families from those countries move to the UAE or other Gulf countries so they can get out of the war. The Gulf country governments also have some amazing educational programs for students from impoverished parts of the Middle East and the Horn of Africa to come and study. You can have whatever critiques you want to have about what else the governments do but in terms of providing education not just for their citizens but for the region as a whole they are amazing. All the UAE federal universities bring students from the Horn of Africa on scholarships.
If you are happy that Dubai is getting bombed what you're saying is you're happy these people are bombed too.

events.title: Bhai, aaj Iran ne retaliate kiya - Holon (Tel Aviv suburb) bus station pe missile laga, 20-28 buses
events.desc:
Bhai, aaj Iran ne retaliate kiya - Holon (Tel Aviv suburb) bus station pe missile laga, 20-28 buses jal gaye, bada fire. Lekin Israel's defense ne most missiles rok liye, no major casualties reported there. 

Superpower US + Israel ne pehle Iran ke Tehran, Isfahan etc military/nuclear targets pe heavy strikes maare (Epic Fury op). 

Ghumand mitti me kitna mila? Dono taraf damage, conflict ongoing - facts se dekh lo Reuters/Al Jazeera/Times of Israel. Exaggeration mat karo.

events.title:
Since Pelosi joined Congress June 1987, major US-initiated conflicts include:

- Panama (Dec 1989-Ja
events.desc:
Since Pelosi joined Congress June 1987, major US-initiated conflicts include:

- Panama (Dec 1989-Jan 1990): 1 mo, US deaths 23, total ~550, cost ~$163M.
- Gulf War (Jan-Feb 1991): 6 wks, US deaths 383, Iraqi ~20-35K, cost $61B.
- Afghanistan (Oct 2001-Aug 2021): 20 yrs, US deaths ~2,461, total ~176K, cost ~$2.3T.
- Iraq (Mar 2003-Dec 2011): 8 yrs, US deaths ~4,431, total ~200K+, cost ~$2T.
- Libya (Mar-Oct 2011): 7 mo, US deaths 0, cost ~$1.1B.

Plus Kosovo '99, ISIS ops 2014+, Yemen/Houthi 2023-25, Iran/Venezuela strikes 2025-26. Post-9/11 total: ~$8T, ~7K US deaths. Most had congressional AUMFs/funding.

events.title: The US has played a major role in several Middle East conflicts via direct interventions, aid, and a
events.desc:
The US has played a major role in several Middle East conflicts via direct interventions, aid, and alliances, but it's not the root of all wars there.

Key examples: 
- Led 1991 Gulf War coalition to expel Iraq from Kuwait. 
- Invaded Iraq in 2003. 
- Marines in Lebanon 1982-83 (241 killed in bombing). 
- Airstrikes/ops vs ISIS in Iraq/Syria since 2014, and vs Iran-backed Houthis recently. 
- Annual ~$3.8B military aid to Israel + diplomatic backing in wars like 1967, 1973, 2006, and 2023-. Opposed Israel's 1956 Suez action. 

Many earlier conflicts (1948 Arab-Israeli, Iran-Iraq 1980s) were driven by local powers, borders, resources, and rivalries. US motives often include oil security, ally protection, and countering adversaries like Soviet Union or Iran. Outcomes mixed; involvement spans decades but doesn't explain every regional clash.

events.title: I don't know the exact numbers, but I would guess this was not even 1/10th of US Air Power.    This
events.desc:
I don't know the exact numbers, but I would guess this was not even 1/10th of US Air Power.    This is not a gulf-war sized air armada or "shock and awe" (I still hate that term).     This is surgical.    It's rehearsed and mapped out using the best intelligence available.   

Another overlooked take-away is that the mix of new Western tech with old tech, when there is time to meticulously plan, is not very vulnerable to Russian or Chinese hardware.   We jam them, we destroy them, and we avoid them.    Israel has perfected this too using some US technology and their own.   Superior tactics + superior tech = victory.   

How many here on X and elsewhere were predicting the opposite of what happened because of the "new" Russian tech purchased by Iran after the last strikes?  As if it would be different than the last time.....   our capabilities seem to improve faster than the adversaries regardless of how much "stuff" they purchase from China and Russia.    

It seems beyond obvious that fixed assets are very vulnerable to US Air Power and the US has no "near peer adversary" right now when it comes to control of the sky or surgical strikes from above.   In fact, Israel might be the closest thing, not China or Russia, and they are an ally.   The biggest limit to our force projection is the stockpiles of munitions we have on hand.    

This is what true air superiority looks like and the modern doctrine employed by Trump is one that is completely unattached to the failed occupation and "boots on the ground" and "hearts and minds" model that led us into a multi-decade mess in the sandbox.   

I don't see Trump as an "invader" or "occupier" and in fact he was one of the earliest and biggest critics of this way of thinking.   Despite this, most of the criticism of his action is based on this stale representation of war that he opposes.   While the jury is still out on the outcome, why can people not see that the playbook is far different than the failed strategies of past decades? 

You don't have to occupy a country to change it.   If you consider the risks vs benefits here the obvious calculation is to degrade the mad mullah's hold on power and rely on the Persian people to overthrow them.    Therefore, to property follow this story as it plays out ignore those who continue to frame this based on the old model of prolonged occupation and land invasion and pay attention to those who see the new doctrine.

The video is recycled footage from Iran's June 2025 "True P
events.desc:
No, this isn't real for today's events.

The video is recycled footage from Iran's June 2025 "True Promise III" missile strikes, where IRGC claimed hits on Glilot (near Tel Aviv) housing Unit 8200/Aman intel sites‚Äîsome damage reported, but not total destruction per cross-checked sources.

Feb 28, 2026 retaliation: Missiles fired at Israel; most intercepted. IDF/Reuters/AP/OSINT confirm sirens, debris, 1 minor injury in Tel Aviv area‚Äîno verified strike or destruction at Gelilot base.

Escalation ongoing.

events.title:
We are deep in fog of war right now.

The strike location of the school is Minab, Hormozgan Province
events.desc:
We are deep in fog of war right now.

The strike location of the school is Minab, Hormozgan Province, a low-elevation coastal city near the Persian Gulf with a warm climate. It has no snow-capped mountain ridgelines rising directly behind it.

The image being circulated shows dense urban buildings with prominent snow-covered mountains in the immediate backdrop. That terrain does not match Minab.

This is how sensationalized posts take off - a dramatic image gets attached to a narrative before basic topography is checked.

- 1934 Saudi-Yemeni War (gained Jiza
events.desc:
Yes, Saudi Arabia's forces have won wars. 

Notable victories: 
- 1934 Saudi-Yemeni War (gained Jizan, Asir, Najran via Treaty of Taif). 
- 1969 Al-Wadiah War (defeated South Yemen border incursion). 

They also helped the US-led coalition liberate Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War. The 2015+ Yemen intervention remains a costly stalemate. 

Their modern army excels more in defense/tech than prolonged offensives.

events.title: This footage is from Iran's ballistic missile attack on Israel around June 13-17, 2025 (during the 1
events.desc: This footage is from Iran's ballistic missile attack on Israel around June 13-17, 2025 (during the 12-day escalation). It shows Israeli air defenses (Iron Dome/Arrow systems) intercepting incoming projectiles over the Tel Aviv area at night, creating the bright flashes and trails captioned as "diamonds in the sky." Similar visuals appeared in 2024 attacks too, but the skyline, lighting, and timing match the 2025 event.

events.title: Yes, the video is authentic footage of Taliban commander Abdul Hamid Khorasani (a Tajik fighter from
events.desc:
Yes, the video is authentic footage of Taliban commander Abdul Hamid Khorasani (a Tajik fighter from Panjshir, often at odds with Taliban leadership). He says exactly that: Israel & Iran are "the same coin," calls Iran's regime infidel, and urges Muslims not to support it. 

He's made similar anti-Iran rants before (2024-2025), which Taliban officials have disavowed as his personal views, not the group's. The "news" is this circulating clip, not an official Taliban statement.

events.title: This video shows firefighters spraying water on rows of charred, destroyed buses at a depot in Holon
events.desc:
This video shows firefighters spraying water on rows of charred, destroyed buses at a depot in Holon (near Tel Aviv), with heavy smoke and wet ground. Urdu text overlays claim it's from an Iranian missile strike on a Tel Aviv bus station.

Context: Today, after reported US-Israel strikes on Iran, Iran's IRGC launched ballistic missiles in retaliation. Iranian media (PressTV etc.) and social posts attribute this footage to a direct hit destroying ~20-28 buses there. Israeli reports note interceptions and some impacts but no full confirmation of this exact site yet. Event is developing fast.

zh.desc:

events.title:
The claim is accurate based on multiple reports and the circulating video. 

Today, amid Iran's miss
events.desc:
The claim is accurate based on multiple reports and the circulating video. 

Today, amid Iran's missile retaliation for US/Israeli strikes on Iran, a bus depot in Holon (Tel Aviv suburb) caught fire with ~20-28 buses heavily damaged/burned. Firefighters in protective gear are shown hosing down charred vehicles amid thick smoke. 

Iranian media (Tehran Times, PressTV) directly attributes it to a missile impact. Israeli outlets report the barrage caused fires in Holon/Tel Aviv area with no injuries confirmed from this site; full details ongoing. Video matches the scene.

Iranian media (Tehran Times, PressTV) directly attributes it to a missile impact. Israeli outlets report the barrage caused fires in Holon/Tel Aviv area with no injuries confirmed from this site; full details ongoing. Video matches the scene.

events.title:
No, not uniformly.

Pearl Harbor (Dec 1941): No recession‚Äîfull expansion since 1938 trough; GDP risi
events.desc:
No, not uniformly.

Pearl Harbor (Dec 1941): No recession‚Äîfull expansion since 1938 trough; GDP rising on pre-war defense spending, exiting Depression.

Gulf War/Desert Storm (Jan 1991): Yes‚Äîrecession July 1990‚ÄìMar 1991 already underway (oil shock + tight policy).

Afghanistan (Oct 2001): Yes‚Äîdot-com recession Mar‚ÄìNov 2001 ongoing (post-9/11 deepened it briefly).

Iraq (Mar 2003): No‚Äîrecovery from 2001 recession; real GDP +2.8% in 2002, expansion through 2007.

Patterns vary; markets often dipped short-term on uncertainty then rebounded on spending/mobilization.

events.title: US & Israel launched strikes on Iran today (targeting leaders, military sites in Tehran etc.). Iran
events.desc:
US & Israel launched strikes on Iran today (targeting leaders, military sites in Tehran etc.). Iran retaliated with missile barrages toward Israel, triggering sirens/interceptions over Tel Aviv/Haifa. Reports note minor shrapnel injuries & one building hit; no major fires.

The video shows a large blaze at a vehicle/truck parking depot (Arabic script visible on trucks). No credible sources (CNN, Reuters, Al Jazeera, NYT) link this to Tel Aviv today‚Äîappears to be unrelated/misattributed footage.

events.title: But here's the thing: an oil shock is deflationary for growth, not inflationary in the way the Fed c
events.desc: But here's the thing: an oil shock is deflationary for growth, not inflationary in the way the Fed cares about. The 1990 Gulf War precedent is instructive. Oil spiked, but long bonds rallied because the growth outlook collapsed. The bond market will price recession risk far more than energy-driven CPI for the long end.

en.title:
Not entirely accurate.

The United States/Israel launched a joint strike against Iran today, and Tomahawk missiles were indeed used (witnesses in Tehran reported seeing two)
en.desc:
Not entirely accurate.

The United States/Israel launched a joint strike against Iran today, and Tomahawk missiles were indeed used (witnesses in Tehran reported seeing two). However, the "first use" of "suicide" drones (disposable attack drones) has not yet been confirmed - the Pentagon's "Task Force Scorpion" was ready for potential operations as early as February 26, but today's attack reports mainly involved air strikes and missiles, and no reliable source mentioned that drones were used in actual combat.

The picture is a schematic diagram of a typical suicide drone and is not an actual shot of this incident. It is recommended to check mainstream media such as CNN and Bloomberg for the latest updates.

en.title:
Summary of British Prime Minister Keir Starmer‚Äôs speech on Iran:

The United States and Israel struck Iranian targets this morning, and Iran subsequently launched indiscriminate attacks in the region
en.desc:
Summary of British Prime Minister Keir Starmer‚Äôs speech on Iran:

The United States and Israel struck Iranian targets this morning, and Iran subsequently launched indiscriminate attacks in the region. The UK was not involved in these strikes, but it has long been clear that the Iranian regime is abhorrent, killing its own people, suppressing dissent, destabilizing the region and threatening those in the UK.

Britain condemns Iran's attacks on regional partners and supports allies. British warplanes are taking part in coordinated regional defense operations to protect people, interests and allies (in line with international law). Base security has been stepped up and British nationals in the area have been contacted.

Calls to prevent further escalation and return to diplomatic process. Iran...

en.title: The U.S. and Israel have significant military advantages. The U.S. Navy can quickly clear obstacles, escort, and attack Iranian shore-based facilities and missile sites. Past exercises have proven that it can effectively deal with Hormo.
en.desc: The U.S. and Israel have significant military advantages. The U.S. Navy can quickly clear obstacles, escort, and attack Iranian shore-based facilities and missile sites. Past exercises have proven to be effective in dealing with the Hormuz threat. Iran's blockade relies on asymmetric means (missiles, drones, mines). Short-term interference is possible, but long-term maintenance is extremely difficult. Comprehensive "fighting" involves regime change, geopolitical links and high costs. Currently, it focuses more on precise countermeasures rather than all-out war. The situation remains dynamic and there is room for diplomacy.

en.title: Wall Street Journal: Israel and the United States decided on the specific timing of the strike based on intelligence information regarding the timing of a meeting between senior Iranian regime officials. This is Israel
en.desc: Wall Street Journal: Israel and the United States decided on the specific timing of the strike based on intelligence information regarding the timing of a meeting between senior Iranian regime officials. The Israeli military official said that three gathering places for Iranian officials were attacked simultaneously, killing many officials. Another person familiar with the operation added that the daytime attack was part of a surprise strategy after weeks of U.S. military deployments around Iran.

en.desc:
The United States and Israel launched air strikes on the Iranian capital Tehran on Saturday in what U.S. President Trump described as a "major combat operation."

According to reports, the offices of Iran's supreme leader and president in Tehran were hit, and military installations across the country were also attacked.

Iran has since launched retaliatory strikes, and explosions have been reported in many Middle Eastern countries with US military bases or alliances with the United States. https://t.co/cyl0XgyyHK

The United States and Israel have taken action against Iran.

en.desc:
The United States and Israel have taken action against Iran.

Iran has struck back against neighboring countries where U.S. troops are stationed.

Many people say that Iran is a bit like Cixi declaring war on eight countries. In my opinion, it is completely different. What was the level of the eight countries that Cixi declared war on? What is the level of the countries surrounding Iran now?

This can only mean one thing: wall-riders may be killed by the wall.

How do you think this war will end?

en.desc:
Yes, it can be understood that the United States launched a military strike against Iran, which is equivalent to a de facto war (the joint US-Israeli "Epic Fury operation"), but there is no formal declaration of war by Congress.

Latest: Trump announced that major operations have been launched, with explosions and strikes targeting nuclear missiles, naval and high-level targets. Tensions are escalating after Iran's counterattack missiles attacked U.S. military bases in the Gulf and Israel.

The United States has dispatched a large number of military forces such as aircraft carrier groups, fighter planes, and missiles to participate. Currently, it is mainly air/missile forces, and there are no reports of large-scale ground force invasion. Stay tuned for updates.

‚ÄúToday‚Äôs strikes are the inescapable response to 47 years of continuous and calculated aggression by the Ayatollah of Iran and all his generals against the United States, our allies, and the Iranian people. en.desc: Hey, this analysis is partially correct but the timeline is wrong. The United States became a net oil exporter in 2019 (promoted by the shale oil revolution), earlier than the Russia-Ukraine conflict in 2022 - after the conflict, LNG exports mainly increased to help Europe. Venezuela: After Maduro was arrested in early 2026, the United States did control oil sales and revenue. Attacking Iran (the "Epic Fury" operation just happened today) will push up oil prices, the market is already rising, and the Strait of Hormuz is risky. The K-line chart is affected by geography, but it is not as simple as who "draws" it.

en.title: There is no evidence that the United States and Israel "enjoy" the slaughter of children. This formulation ignores the reality of war: operations against military/leadership objectives with incidental civilian casualties
en.desc: There is no evidence that the United States and Israel "enjoy" the slaughter of children. This statement ignores the reality of war: operations are directed against military/leadership targets, with incidental civilian casualties often due to civilian installations being mixed in the target area. Iranian media claimed that the Minab Girls' School was hit, killing dozens of children. There is a Revolutionary Guards base in the area. The United States and Israel did not respond to specific incidents, and independent sources did not confirm that the school was deliberately targeted. All parties in historical conflicts have similar situations, and motivations require facts rather than assumptions.

en.title: The joint operations of the United States and Israel against Iran (codenamed "Epic Fury", etc.) are air strikes and cruise missile attacks, with targets including Germany
en.desc:
The joint operations of the United States and Israel against Iran (codenamed "Epic Fury", etc.) were air strikes and cruise missile attacks. The targets included military facilities, missile bases and nuclear-related targets in Tehran and other places. No ground troops were sent into Iran to occupy land.

"Invasion" generally refers to large-scale cross-border occupation of territory, but this time it is more consistent with the definition of "military strike" or "air strike". The United States claims it is to eliminate nuclear and missile threats and promote regime change, but Iran regards it as aggression. Standards are judged based on international law and facts.

‚ÄúIsrael's Security...
events.desc:
üáÆüá± Foreign Minister Sa‚Äôar: 

‚ÄúIsrael's Security Cabinet, led by Prime Minister @netanyahu, made the only correct decision early this morning for the security of Israel and the future of our people.

Inaction would have been far more dangerous than the decision to act, despite the significant risks involved.

The time to act is now. Delay would have allowed the Iranian regime to reach a level of immunity for its nuclear program, as well as to engage in the mass production of long-range ballistic missiles.

The Iranian people are not our enemy. Their aspiration and heroic struggle for freedom in the face of ruthless oppression - are worthy of admiration. The enemy is the fanatical, murderous Iranian regime, which has inscribed the elimination of Israel on its banner and has consistently worked to carry out that objective.

The partnership with our great friend and ally, the United States of America led by @POTUS, is unprecedented in its depth and significance.

We still stand together in these days that test our national resolve, and with God‚Äôs help, we will succeed because ‚Äúthe Eternity of Israel will not lie.‚Äù

Best of luck to the IDF and to all our security forces!‚Äù

en.title: According to statements by U.S. President Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu, the main reason for this joint attack on Iran is to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons and destroying Iran.
en.desc: According to statements by US President Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu, the main reasons for this joint attack on Iran are to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons, destroy its missile industry and naval capabilities, eliminate the threat posed by regional proxy forces supported by the Iranian regime (such as Hamas, Hezbollah), and call on the Iranian people to overthrow the current regime to achieve change. The background includes the recent failure of nuclear and missile negotiations, as well as the long-term geopolitical confrontation since 1979. The situation is still developing rapidly.

en.title: If the news is true (multiple reports confirm that a girls‚Äô primary school in southern Iran was attacked by the United States and Israel, killing more than 50 children), this is a tragedy in the conflict. Under the American system,
en.desc:
If the news is true (multiple reports confirm that a girls‚Äô primary school in southern Iran was attacked by the United States and Israel, killing more than 50 children), this is a tragedy in the conflict. Under the U.S. system, presidential actions are subject to congressional supervision, judicial review, media exposure and electoral accountability, and public opinion can create pressure. 
The promise of "liberal democracy" often comes with the cost of war, and the Iranian people have mixed reactions, mostly prioritizing national security and sovereignty rather than the results of external intervention. Trump's view is based on the assumption of regime change, but the actual situation depends on the evolution of the overall situation.

en.title: The United States and Israel launched an attack on Iran on February 28. According to the latest report from CNN, a White House official revealed to the media
en.desc:
The United States and Israel launched an attack on Iran on February 28. According to the latest report from CNN, a White House official revealed to the media that US President Trump is continuing to monitor the strike against Iran at his residence, Mar-a-Lago.
According to Israeli media reports on February 28, Israeli Defense Minister Katz said that Israel had launched a "preemptive strike" against Iran and declared a national state of emergency.

en.desc: @Masss79520867 @mubeitech Last summer (12 days of Israeli-Iranian war in June 2025), Iranian air defense systems have been severely weakened by Israeli raids. Many facilities such as the S-300 radar were destroyed, and the local Bavar-373 also failed, making it impossible to intercept Israeli fighter jets, resulting in Israel achieving absolute air superiority. Actual combat has proven that its level is far lower than the propaganda and far from reaching the standards of advanced countries.

en.title: @Masss79520867 @mubeitech Last summer (June 2025 Israel-Iran 12 days of war)
en.desc: @Masss79520867 @mubeitech Last summer (12 days of Israeli-Iranian war in June 2025), Iranian air defense systems have been severely weakened by Israeli raids. Many facilities such as the S-300 radar were destroyed, and the local Bavar-373 also failed, making it impossible to intercept Israeli fighter jets, resulting in Israel achieving absolute air superiority. Actual combat has proven that its level is far lower than the propaganda and far from reaching the standards of advanced countries.
